Neybrly

Living in big city can be isolating. It is difficult to get to know your neighbours when interactions are few and far between.

The goal is to design an app that helps improve the well-being of people living in isolating environments by providing users the ability to engage in neighbourly activities.

What people want

Surveys provided me with a quick way to collect data and formulate a picture of participant backgrounds, needs and challenges of being neigbhourly. It would have been preferable to have a larger sample size but I was happy with the diverse background of the participants and the fact patterns emerged from the data. These patterns helped in developing a persona and journey map which will help steer the direction of the visual design.

Browsing, buying goods and selling goods emerged as the most common activities on popular community sites.

Mapping out the app

An early draft of a sitemap based on user input. A feed is a primary feature as browsing was the most popular activity from collected data. Naturally, this map will change based on user feedback.

Wireflow

Neighbours are warm, helpful and friendly

I chose a pastel, vintage colour palette coupled with a round font in order to evoke a sense of warmth, playfulness, and friendliness that users can relate to when they think of neighbourly attributes. The design aesthetics are clean, simple and intuitive. Vibrant imagery and a warm, welcoming red for it's brand colour were selected to represent the energy and spirit of the brand.

Prototype

Summary

Research findings challenged assumptions of what features should be prioritized in this app. Surveys responses said the majority of participants were already content with their neighbourhoods and they generally used community apps to buy & sell goods. Surveys given to any random audience can cast a wide range of answers one is seeking as a researcher but finding patterns in the data is still worth the effort. Interviews told me a different story which included challenges of affordability, safety, and transparency for renters.
